bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to T.H.D. Griffitts, March 29, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] comments on malaria control and sends Griffitts a recent lecture he gave on the subject. [Carter] requests information on breeding areas of the three Anopheles species mosquitos.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to T.H.D. Griffitts, March 29, 1922
div1.opener:
Mal
Griffitts
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
, D. C.
March 29, 1922.
Dear Griffitts:
div1.p:
I don't quite know what the State Board means by “Medical End of
Malaria Control.” I am inclined to think I would make it mean simply
the preventive fact of curing the patient who has malaria as he comes
to the medical man. In isolated houses this should be quite a protection:
For people who live in juxta position to others it is more questionable.
Naturally, this latter depends on the existence or no of a “homing in-
stinct” in Anopheles. If you remember, I brought this question up
in a remark on your and LePrince's flight experiments at Fort Lawn
and it seems to be held--tentatively at least--by quite a number of
men--though, I think, on insufficient grounds--that is, there is evi-
dence for it, but no proof. S. B. James: Seller: Grassi and Fermi all
preach it and de Buse of New Orleans, incidentally does the same.

The use of quinine as a protection to the individual taking it--
or its general use to protect the community is a different thing, which
you may use your own judgment about taking up. In my judgment neither
are methods of election, and yet both have a value and, at times, be-
come methods of election.

I am enclosing you a copy of what is more or less a lecture that
I have just given on the same subject to the Johns Hopkins School of
Hygiene in Baltimore. It is not exactly as I delivered it, but not
very different. Welch and Frost thought well of it.

1/ The different breeding places of our three species of Anopheles--
I am especially anxious to get all the data upon the breeding places of
the “quads” that I can:--I mean, of course, breeding of sanitary importance--
1/2 dozen make no difference. Especially do I want to know of their small
pool and cow track breeding, which we did not find on the Coosa nor Parr
Shoals, nor did I find it last year on the Wateree.

2/ I am sending you a copy of a letter that I have just written to
Bruns in New Orleans. Take that as your second problem, please.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General. 2 enclosures.
